titleStmt.title: M112 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M112 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5p. p. 33 with fragment paginated p. 30 on verso.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

But again down on the Bankside the curtain rises.
The trumpets sound; the flag blows and the
shadowy insubstantial life txmxmxx of Squires, nobles

Maids of
hnour honour and country
gentlmen gentlemen is before us.
In one second we are in the thick of love; murder; adultery.
Yorkshire is before us. There is Frankland and his wife;

there is Wendoll the
adulterere adulterer ; and Acton the villain.
Supper is laid; the cards are on the table, and next moment
the husband throwing open the door sees his wife lying in
the arms of her lover. The yellow pages in Record offices

and Muniments rooms
wit with their
contorsions contortions , their evasions,

give place to outright speech. In the play
tself itself all is

evident,
outapoken outspoken . In
r al real life all is shadowy and
suppressed.

But by
degrrees degrees the dramatist sheds his anonymity.
He separates himself from his audience. He pauses, sometimes;

he
di erts diverts the interest from the action to the
mtove motive
motive behind the action. What, he broods in a Woman killed
with kindness, is the effect of mercy?--- if the adulters
are confronted not with death but with a guilty conscience?
As the plays come faster and faster, as the curtain rises

again and again, upon
Marloew Marlowe , Kyd, Heywood,
Marts n Marston
Tourneur, Ford-- anonymity and the pressure of the
audience cease to bind the playwright. The reader loses his

anonymity too. He
chhoses chooses ; he
discrimitaes discriminates . Here are
kick nacks knicknacks ; curiosities; illustrations of the time. But
here on the other hand, what we call for short ourselves--

the thought that we think
instcintively instinctively , the comment that

that of the Stanleys, the Cxmxmxxxx

the Herberts and above all the
Cliffo ds Cliffords has become

like a precious stone not to be
mized mixed with baser metal.

p.l:
She
believss believes in the immortality of the body as firmly as
in the immortality of the soul.
Yet there were moments when even this carapace of
possessions proved too heavy for her; when on the first day
xmxmxmxmmxmxx If I had not excellent Chaucer's book

many troubles as I have here, but when I read in that,

I
nscorn scorn and make light of them all, and a little part of
his beauteous spirit infuses itself in me."

p.l:
She adds that
postcriot postscript wxmxmxmxmxmx to a letter about a
little cabinet and cup which she had left with Lady Kent
when she borrowed a hundred pounds of her.
But it is only when she reads that she comments.
When she goes to the play she says only "Supped with

l.quote: my Lord and Lady Arundel and after supper

l.quote: "We stood to see the Masque in the box with my Lady

presumably that the reader was born. xmxmxmxmxmxmxm
